specs/victoria/approved/volume-backed-se.message: It is incorrect. If delete_on_termination=True, it means that will be delete the instance attached volume when you delete the instnace. Or I missed something?
yes, you are right.

This sentence seems contradictory.

delete_on_termination=True: deleting the attached(old) volume when you delete the instance.

delete_on_termination=False: preserve the attached(old) volume when you delete the instance.

I think we dont change the delete_on_termination's meaning https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/branch/master/api-ref/source/parameters.yaml#L2295

Victoria

ok.I will do it.
s/Proposed/Approved
.. so that I can upgrade the guest OS in my volume backed server.
nit: missing space
only compute service version needs to be bumped, the RPC version remains the same as no RPC is changed.

I thought we were using compute traits to identify new functionality like this as we did with volume backed rescue?

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/6d6b8b45228a9d8b934b5350c48b3066d7474527/nova/compute/api.py#L4215-L4223
This function isn't change the virt driver, maybe we should not use the compute traits.
So the instance.host check above would need to be *after* the instance had been rescheduled but before we spawn correct?
why? Shouldn't we check the nova-compute service version in compute/api.py?
Can you link to the Cinder spec for this?
the spec is in the last reference
I think it would be better to state that this is happening within the compute manager (nova.compute.manager) and not the virt driver.
I'm assuming this means os-reimage is async?
yes
I wouldn't use that term here, we wouldn't be swapping attached volumes, just replacing one with another offline.

Lee was right on PS6. In between Stein and Victoria, we now want to provide traits for compute services for knowing what they can support.

Also, if you provide a trait, then when rebuilding, the scheduler would verify this trait so only the compute services supporting this would be agreed, you wouldn't need to verify the host directly.
nit: If
reimage, rebuild
This should check the cinder if support reimage the root volume, yeah?
Done
this should only happen if the image is different the the current image to similarly be consitent as we only go to the schduler if the image changes in the non bfv case.
ok, I delete it.

an alternitive to poll would have been to add a new external event.
like we use for volume-extend already or interaction with neutron and cyborg

https://github.com/openstack/nova/blob/e1d61f6bf41ffcfdb06df09433db7b984fa9f1bc/nova/api/openstack/compute/schemas/server_external_events.py#L57


that would be the more efficient way to do this as nova would just yield execution of the coroutenie and work on other task while it waited for cinder to complete the reimage.
yes, you are right
note to me : since we only call Cinder API by the nova-compute service, this is async and we can't return a HTTP400 to the user like the existing behaviour.
This means that the cinder-nova interaction has been changed. Does cinder devs are OK with this?

this was the main change i asked for.
you are right that this changes the nova cinder interaction by replacing the poll with waiting for a notification
but since cinder already has the infrastructure to notify nova of a resize via an event it should be easy to extend that functionality this this new uscase and it will significantly reduce the load on the cinder api as a result.

it would be good to have the cinder team reivew this change to ensure they are ok with this but the polling behavior before makes me somewhat uncomfortable with how this might scale which was one of the reason i asked for the cahgne.
the other was consitency with how we interfact with neutron and cyborg. this came up in the cyborg deiscussion which also originally suggested polling but that was repleaced with an arq bound event in a similar way so i think we should default to an external event where possible instead of polling.

We need to have some way to make sure that the cinder we're talking to is new enough to send that event, so that a new-nova-oldish-cinder configuration doesn't hang for a long time waiting for the event that will never come.

I'm pro-event, but just want to make sure that we have that base covered here. Apologies if I missed some detail that makes this obvious in the recent history.

yes so the privious line is "Call the new ``os-reimage`` cinder API."

so i assume we woudl have to detect if that api exists proably via a microverions i guess. if that is being added in victoria and has not yet merged then we could jus tuse the microverion fo that new api to detect support.

if the os-reimage api has been added alredy i guess we could still add a new microversion for sending the evnet.

we could fall back to polling i guess if the os-reimage is available but the event is not avaiable.

looking at the specs repo it was added in train.

https://specs.openstack.org/openstack/cinder-specs/specs/train/add-volume-re-image-api.html

hum looks like there is no microverions listed ?
https://docs.openstack.org/cinder/latest/contributor/api_microversion_history.html#maximum-in-stein-and-train

did cinder forget to add one for this new volume action?

as Dan stated, there is a crucial upgrade path that needs to make sure that nova doesn't hold for an event that will never be triggered if Cinder isn't recent enough.

The problem is that you're not telling what becomes the instance after asking to be rebuilt if Cinder isn't recent enough. Should it turn back to an ACTIVE state or should we go into ERROR ? Somehow we'll stop in the middle of the operation and we would have deleted the old volume attachment already.
see, we're doing the Cinder call after a desctructive action, which is to delete the original volume attachment. I'd prefer to switch both steps.

I think we can do an initial query to cinder if it supports the reimage functionality then start with all these steps. The problem with switching steps is current implementation doesn't support re-image of in-use volume and sequence of these steps call reimage API with volume status as reserved.

In addition to that note, this sentence will have to be clarified: https://opendev.org/openstack/nova/src/commit/6d99aa68f1dd6b730ea9a4866afcc6514bfabddd/api-ref/source/servers-actions.inc#L541

When the volume is re-imaged, all current content on the volume will be *destroyed*.  We need to be explicit about that, because people expect volumes to be "persistent storage", and any data they've put into the volume is going to disappear when they rebuild the instance.

From an API perspective, a rebuild means a destructive/reconstructive action but I agree with you, this absolutely has to be explicitely documented in the API docs, in the ops docs and within the relnotes.

ansible/roles/ovs-dpdk/tasks/config.yml.message: I assume this is supported by this script in the rocky image?

commands:
  - install:
    - installs ovs-dpdkctl as a systemd service.
    - installs ovs-dpdkctl binary.
    - generates ovs-dpdkctl configuration file.
    - starts ovs-dpdkctl service.
  - uninstall:
    - stops ovs-dpdkctl service.
    - uninstalls ovs-dpdkctl systemd service.
    - uninstalls ovs-dpdkctl binary.
    - removes ovs-dpdkctl configuration file.
  - bind_nics:
    - iterates over all dpdk interfaces defined in ovs-dpdkctl config
      and binds the interface to the target driver specifed in the config
      if current driver does not equal target.
  - unbind_nics:
    - iterates over all dpdk interfaces defined in ovs-dpdkctl config
      and restores the interface to its original non dpdk driver.
  - init:
    - defines dpdk specific configuration paramater in the ovsdb.
    - creates bridges as spcified by ovs bridge_mappings in
      ovs-dpdkctl config.
    - creates dpdk ports as defined by ovs port_mappings in
      ovs-dpdkctl config.
  - usage:
    - prints this message

tox.ini.message: I think this is not the right solution as the upper constraints are used below in deps. Instead of this 'double' definition of upper constraints I recommend to use the constraints explicitly for 'docs' tox target.

replace this to below lines would fix the issue:

deps = -c{env:TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/victoria}
       -r{toxinidir}/doc/requirements.txt
       -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt
       -r{toxinidir}/test-requirements.txt

(sphinx installs 'requirements' (i.e. requirements.txt) anyway, so it needs to be added here so that they will be installed with constraints)

actually, it is enough without test-requirements.txt, like this:

deps = -c{env:TOX_CONSTRAINTS_FILE:https://releases.openstack.org/constraints/upper/victoria}
       -r{toxinidir}/doc/requirements.txt
       -r{toxinidir}/requirements.txt

templates/default-ssl.message: Is this the right section to put the secure flag? "enforce_ssl" is whether to redirect HTTP access to HTTPS, and not related to the decision if SSL is used or not.

My point is that in the case where ssl=true and enforce_ssl(redirection)=false, users can use HTTP and HTTPS respectively. However, I don't think users acknowledge that cookies fetched over HTTPS connections are to be reused over HTTP connection.

I think we should just set Secure flag on the HTTPS connection regardless enforce_ssl is true or false.

Indeed.  The 'Secure' flag tells the browser that it can't use the cookie for requests that don't go via https (or wss).  So if 'must use ssl' config is set, then, adding Secure ensures that the browser (or rather Angular) won't make calls to http:// rather than https://  -- at least that's my reading of the spec?

Wondered if this adds duplicate Secure flags although it might not be harmful. I enabled some secure flags in Django so we might want to consolidate the flag into apache2 as a reverse proxy by dropping flags from Django.
https://opendev.org/openstack/charm-openstack-dashboard/commit/47396b52dea795548a22e71fe8e51a414c7d300d

It makes me wonder where/how https://bugs.launchpad.net/charm-openstack-dashboard/+bug/1822751 arose in the first case, as that postdates the change in django.  I'm wondering if it's code served as a static via Apache, or some other code path in Django (e.g. earlier).

Header edit runs before Django gets to see, generate the request.  If we run "Header always edit", then I could do something like:

    Header always edit Set-Cookie "^(.*)([Ss]ecure\s*;)(.*)$" "$1$2"
    Header edit Set-Cookie (.*) $1;Secure

This would guarantee that it is only set once.  I'd have to play with the regex to get it to work with Secure ;Secure and Secure; !

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message:
Yeah after sleeping on this, I'm thinking that by fixing one race I've probably introduced another race.  By immediately waking up the eventloop to call _hard_reset, we've now got a situation where the eventloop can start cleaning up via _hard_reset, while at the same time the pyngus callback is still running.

I didn't notice this in my initial testing because I was abusing the fact that the original race is easy to reproduce with nova-api/eventlet/wsgi.  But I think because eventlet is being used it was artificially eliminating this second race since the eventloop greenthread couldn't run until the pyngus callback finished and yielded the eventlet scheduler.

I'll think about this a bit more.

recheck

Hello,

With these changes sometimes tests timed out locally and on the gates.
Especially the `test_amqp_driver` testing module [1].

Each time I run the test with your changes I can see the following traceback in the logs:

```
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "/usr/lib64/python3.8/threading.py", line 932, in _bootstrap_inner
    self.run()
  File "/home/hberaud/dev/redhat/upstream/openstack/oslo/oslo.messaging/oslo_messaging/_drivers/amqp1_driver/eventloop.py", line 348, in run
    self._main_loop()
  File "/home/hberaud/dev/redhat/upstream/openstack/oslo/oslo.messaging/oslo_messaging/_drivers/amqp1_driver/eventloop.py", line 392, in _main_loop
    self._requests.process_requests()
  File "/home/hberaud/dev/redhat/upstream/openstack/oslo/oslo.messaging/oslo_messaging/_drivers/amqp1_driver/eventloop.py", line 268, in process_requests
    r()
  File "/home/hberaud/dev/redhat/upstream/openstack/oslo/oslo.messaging/oslo_messaging/_drivers/amqp1_driver/controller.py", line 1112, in _start_shutdown
    if self._active:
  File "/home/hberaud/dev/redhat/upstream/openstack/oslo/oslo.messaging/oslo_messaging/_drivers/amqp1_driver/controller.py", line 1334, in _active
    self._socket_connection.pyngus_conn.active)
AttributeError: 'NoneType' object has no attribute 'active'
```

That's not the case without these changes. I can't reproduce this error without these changes, so I suppose something needs to be adapted on the testing side too.

The problem appear within `TestCyrusAuthentication.test_authentication_failure` [1][2] but I suppose the problem the real problem is more or less located in the method `TestCyrusAuthentication._authentication_test` which is called by this test.

It looks like to a race condition with the active connection.

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/branch/master/oslo_messaging/tests/drivers/test_amqp_driver.py#L879
[2] .tox/py38/bin/python -m testtools.run oslo_messaging.tests.drivers.test_amqp_driver.TestCyrusAuthentication.test_authentication_failure
[3] https://opendev.org/openstack/oslo.messaging/src/branch/master/oslo_messaging/tests/drivers/test_amqp_driver.py#L855

Actually I think v2 may be enough to fix this.  It looks like the tests were failing because _hard_reset gets called immediately, which in turn ultimately calls eventloop._SocketConnection.reset(), and that method sets self.pyngus_conn = None.

Meanwhile, Controller._active was checking self._socket_connection and self._socket_connection.pyngus_conn.active, but wasn't considering that pyngus_conn could be None.  So I just added an additional check for that case.  Running the unit tests a few times locally seems to pass consistently now.  We'll see what Zuul has to say about it.

Adding Stephen who can hopefully give another +2 here.

For some context, I have been running this in private CI for a week now.  Without this patch, tempest fails 100% of the time due to the race triggering when nova-api reconnects after missing heartbeats (which hopefully will get fixed with https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/oslo.messaging/+/810510 when I finish sorting it out).  With this patch included, the reconnects work properly and tempest has been passing 100% for me.

I was having a hard time following the implementation yesterday.

The use-case is a little easier to explain. To experience the problem, all you have to do is configure neutron to use `neutron.conf [oslo_policy] enforce_scope = True` and start using project-admin tokens for system-admin APIs. You'll see that project-admins are allowed to do things they shouldn't be allowed to do because the scope_types check is short-circuited.

This is because neutron subclasses the Check object, and ultimately the BaseCheck object, allowing checks in neutron to hit this code path.

So the use case is to continue letting neutron implement their custom checks [0][1], while maintaining scope enforcement using scope_types on the rules. This check might fall into that category since it's using rule:network_owner, which leverages the FieldCheck class in it's check string [2].

Slawek will have to keep me honest here about what's actually going on. I could be standing in left field by my self 😊

IIUC neutron subclasses the BaseCheck object, which makes it an instance of that object and it executes in this if statement, which doesn't do anything which scope types.

Traditionally, the rule is a string which hits the else check below and that's where we originally implemented scope type checks.

instead of L1054, we can check here if rule.scope_type is set or not. and let _enforce_scope() method make sure it check the scope type if it is called. Otherwise L1054 can give silent pass when registered rule itself forget to set scope_type.

I think we should not have this check which can give false/silent pass if by mistake we forget the scope_type in registered rule itself. and for BaseChecks type rule we check this condition at L1010 itself.

Thank you for your comment, and I'm sorry for the late reply.
To cause this issue, I need to cause the ScaleOut operation fail at "error_point=6" or "error_point=7". So I made it fail in a MgmtDriver called from the scale_end[1].

A simple explanation of the contents is as follows. However, I think it's hard to know what you are without sample. Therefore I have prepared a sample patch[2] to cause this issue. Please refer to the sample patch[2] for more information.


<Explanation of the setting to make it fail>

The scale_end function of the MgmtDriver implement as follows.

<e.g. fail_mgmt.py>
---
    def scale_end(self, context, vnf_instance, scale_vnf_request, grant,
                  grant_request, **kwargs):
        raise exceptions.MgmtDriverOtherError(
            error_message="Failed to scale_end")
---
Reference to [3] for a sample MgmtDriver.

And, add the node_templates.VNF.interface and artifacts in a VNFD as follows.
---
  node_templates:
    VNF:
      type: company.provider.VNF
      properties:
        flavour_description: A simple flavour
      interfaces:
        Vnflcm:
          instantiate_end:
          terminate_end: []
          heal_start: []
          heal_end: []
          scale_start: []
          scale_end:
            implementation: mgmt-drivers-fail                    <- add
      artifacts:                                                 <-
        mgmt-drivers-fail:                                       <-
          description: Management driver for kubernetes cluster  <-
          type: tosca.artifacts.Implementation.Python            <-
          file: Scripts/fail_mgmt.py                             <-
---
Now, the MgmtDriver runs after VNF scales.

Moreover, the configuration of Tacker must be set up in advance.
Could you please reference to [4] for the tacker configuration settings to the MgmtDriver.

[1] https://github.com/openstack/tacker/blob/master/tacker/vnflcm/vnflcm_driver.py#L972-L979
[2] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/tacker/+/815612
[3] https://github.com/openstack/tacker/blob/master/samples/mgmt_driver/kubernetes_mgmt.py

----

Starting with the v5.x kernels asynchronous device scanning is enabled by default to speed up the boot process. This results in device detection order and thus naming potentially changing from one boot to the next, affecting disk and USB storage device names.

We revert two related patches, returning the kernel device naming convention of pre-v5.x kernels. Since we are slotting a 5.10 kernel into a fairly old userspace, this is preferred approach versus adapting the userspace to this new kernel behavior, at least at this time.

NOTE: BIOS and other factors outside the kernel's control may still result in different device naming, users should be aware of this if performing firmware updates. In the long term different approaches will be required to determine which devices to use that don't rely on device names, allowing the original 5.10 kernel behavior to work as designed.

----

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: I'll give similar feedback to what I provided on https://review.opendev.org/c/zuul/zuul-jobs/+/813253/. I think it is better to create a FIPS job for unittests that you can inherit from instead of adding this as a flag to the generic job. The vast majority of zuul users will never need or want to think about FIPS and adding flags for that to these generic jobs is overhead for those users.

The problem about that is that the final jobs that will use it, inherits from: swift-tox-func-py36-centos-8, that inherits from swift-tox-func-py38 and from swift-tox-base < openstack-tox-py27 < openstack-tox < tox <  unittests; So we would need a fips version for each one of these, because they all need to have the exactly same behaviour, only changing if fips would be used or not.
Done

templates/uwsgi.ini.j2.message: should we allow to conditionally provide ca-cert as well?

No I do not believe we should, as this is a server when a client connects it will send its tls certificate along with any intermediate certificates required for the client to verify trust (this may include the ca, but doesn't need to), so the CA is not required in a server. 
A CA cert would only be required in a server if we implemented client auth, which is currently not setup.

deployment/haproxy/haproxy-container-pup.message: don't you need to specify some startmsg.regex here as well?

Thanks for the eyes, Bogdan! I'm not 100% sure the answer since I have not had an opportunity to try deploying haproxy without pacemaker to check what the logs look like in that case.

The default regex of "^[0-9]{4}-[0-9]{2}-[0-9]{2} [0-9]{2}:[0-9]{2}:[0-9]{2}(.[0-9]+ [0-9]+)? (DEBUG|INFO|WARNING|ERROR) " applies to all services unless they are overridden here, and virtually all services use the default because they output lines like this:

2021-12-03 15:39:00.323 11 INFO nova.api.openstack.requestlog [...]

Pacemaker outputs a different format, which is why we supply the regex when running under pacemaker[1]. Here is a sample of HAProxy log while running under pacemaker:

Dec  3 15:40:12 controller-0 haproxy[21]: [...]

[1] https://bugzilla.redhat.com/show_bug.cgi?id=2026290#c5

sushy/resources/sessionservice/sessionse.message:
This seems to fix the original issue, though now it looks there is a side effect with this change: sushy now falls back to basic auth. Was this intended?

Because of this being re-raised here, it's not being handled at [1] and gets till [2] that falls back to basic auth. Sushy still works, but it will never create sessions following [1].

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/commit/1101ac55aff333f856c898d34c9999379a0e71d5/sushy/auth.py#L159
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/commit/1101ac55aff333f856c898d34c9999379a0e71d5/sushy/auth.py#L238

I'm just thinking what's the difference compared to version where Redfish Sessions are not supported at all. Now the SessionService code is executed where it tries to create Redfish Session but it fails and falls back to Basic auth. Why not skip it and go to basic auth at the very beginning and avoid trying initiate Redfish sessions that will never succeed.

About fixing Redfish Sessions - have to rethink how this is implemented and used. I don't know the history of this implementation and what was discussed before, but looking at the current code problem starts with that `/SessionService` needs authenticated user and sushy wants to instantiate this class before authenticated communication is established, hence this `AccessError` handling.

One solution could be to bypass accessing `/SessionService` before POST to `/SessionService/Sessions` is made (that currently is SessionService.create_session, e.g., Session should be created without instantiating `SessionService` that connects to Redfish API too early). This goes against how currently sushy is handling all the resources and that it needs to figure out the URL for `/SessionService/Sessions`.

After this, could remove all this `except` block unless somebody needs to have that log message. This currently no longer handles AccessError as it is still anticipated by [1]^.

Or maybe need to take another step back and look at why `/SessionService` needs authenticated user. I'm looking from iDRAC's implementation, maybe other BMCs don't have it and this is all workaround for iDRACs?

Looking at the original patch [3] it says

  Implement Redfish Sessions because some vendor implementations
  have disabled basic auth and require a Redfish Session to access
  resources. 

From what I see now, if these vendors are also authenticating `/SessionService`, then for them there is no working basic auth fallback.

[3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/sushy/+/471942

author.name: Julia Kreger
author.status: On the moon! With a jetpack!

sushy/resources/sessionservice/sessionse.message:
> I'm just thinking what's the difference compared to version where Redfish Sessions are not supported at all. Now the SessionService code is executed where it tries to create Redfish Session but it fails and falls back to Basic auth. Why not skip it and go to basic auth at the very beginning and avoid trying initiate Redfish sessions that will never succeed.


Well, in the case which was reported to us, it was already authenticated, went to re-authenticate again after loosing connectivity for an intermediate time, and was unable to re-authenitcate period whilst in the mean time things expired.

> 
> About fixing Redfish Sessions - have to rethink how this is implemented and used. I don't know the history of this implementation and what was discussed before, but looking at the current code problem starts with that `/SessionService` needs authenticated user and sushy wants to instantiate this class before authenticated communication is established, hence this `AccessError` handling.

This is true, but in re-auth cases that is always going to happen. In a sense, this could also happen and have the exact same result.

0) Ironic opens a session with sushy
1) Operator changes user password in bmc.
2) Operator changes password in ironic
3) Ironic, because it doesn't track on password changes (likely a bug too) for the cache, it re-uses the session from the cache.
4) The cached session has cached credentials, of course, and attempts utilize a resource
5) Resource auth fails, session re-auth occurs. and we hit this error as the data was bad and it can't even find the path for the Session Service at this point.

I guess that is an encouraging reason we *do* need the exception. And thinking about it, it seems like AccessError *does* likely need to be independently caught of SushyError and likely just raise that all the way back out to the client.

> 
> One solution could be to bypass accessing `/SessionService` before POST to `/SessionService/Sessions` is made (that currently is SessionService.create_session, e.g., Session should be created without instantiating `SessionService` that connects to Redfish API too early). This goes against how currently sushy is handling all the resources and that it needs to figure out the URL for `/SessionService/Sessions`.
> 

Yeah. :\ It is a possibility as well. In a sense vendor inconsistency on accessing /SessionService and if credentials are validated or not if supplied... just doesn't help us here.

> After this, could remove all this `except` block unless somebody needs to have that log message. This currently no longer handles AccessError as it is still anticipated by [1]^.

The logging is useful. Without it I would have never figured out what was going on. So personally, I'd prefer to keep it.

> 
> Or maybe need to take another step back and look at why `/SessionService` needs authenticated user. I'm looking from iDRAC's implementation, maybe other BMCs don't have it and this is all workaround for iDRACs?
> 
> Looking at the original patch [3] it says
> 
>   Implement Redfish Sessions because some vendor implementations
>   have disabled basic auth and require a Redfish Session to access
>   resources. 
> 
> From what I see now, if these vendors are also authenticating `/SessionService`, then for them there is no working basic auth fallback.
> 
> [3] https://review.opendev.org/c/openstack/sushy/+/471942

I don't believe /SessionService is *supposed* to enforce authentication because it is supposed to be discover-able to non-authenticatd or re-authenticating clients, but it is one of those fine detail points which is easy to gloss over. 

I could also be very wrong on /SessionService. My memory is a little fuzzy and I'd have to pull up the standard to be sure at this point.

I guess there are actually *several* conundrums. If a library client wants to access the session service, we shouldn't always force them to loose their internal credentials, which means we would almost need to build a custom request handling pipeline for the /SessionService. Which seems like a lot of code and risk.

sushy/resources/sessionservice/sessionse.message:
*sigh*

Moving on!

Okay, I now understand what your saying after also prototyping it locally.  I'm going to revert all of the merged patches and start over on this because you are right, it is a technical regression, one for which we *do* need a test to ensure we cover.

In other news, it didn't have a semi-broken session service when it failed previously. It would have still worked. What was failing was the actual object load of the resource  allowing it to authenticate.

I think the issue is actually garbage auth data poisoning the underlying request. So maybe the key is to clear it, retry, try and proceed.

That *should* fix the underlying issue when the case occurs, keeping the ability to ultimately try and recover. I feel like we need a "Yes, session auth works" flag to halt any possible fallback, but that is likely a bit more invasive. It would help guard a full fallback lockout of the client.... I guess. And if we know it works from a prior attempt, we could *then* actually raise an AccessError exception up if we're unable to re-auth instead of falling back.

If you've got an idea there I'm welcome to it, but I still think we do need to raise the access error there because even if we go back into session auth with the same client object, we're likely still in a bad state which caused us to get there in the first place.

1) The doc you linked yesterday lists 2 ways how to get Sessions URL [1]
2) sushy already implements both ways, preferring the one that does not require auth (getting the link from root's property), see [2]
3) Even when finding the Sessions URL from unauthenticated root, sushy still creates an instance for resource that requires auth [3]

5) After this patch, that contract/workaround is broken because it no longer handles creating SessionService instance before POSTing credentials
6) If previously established contract/workaround is broken as it turned out faulty, then it should be fixed as part of this solution for this issue so that it both fixes the reported issue and still keeps using Sessions. BMC support for sessions is fine.

[1] https://www.dmtf.org/sites/default/files/standards/documents/DSP0266_1.14.1.pdf, section 15.3.4.1
[2] https://opendev.org/openstack/sushy/src/commit/528d502520c48f64d440a713fd2d4d5e8a9d1abe/sushy/auth.py#L154

So I 'm thinking the original change here is correct even more now. connector.py:135 does the exact same thing when refresh fails. The underlying issue is the library will never fail back as you noted.

But should be fail back be a feature?

If we fail authentication in basic auth, we get AccessError. The ironic side of this is what should go "wait a second, lets start over here".

I guess I'm worried trying to pull us back out of basic auth mode, while easy in theory, is additionally problematic because we're adding more complexity and trying to mask from the API client consumer that a hard error has occurred. The result could be that the hard error may end up in a loop if we do it on any standard response handling either, which i think becomes more and more risky the closer we get to _op in connection.py

I will add details on the manage/unmanage tests that I've done - I think they are all covered. 

The endpoint status out-of-sync is an interesting one, in that all endpoints statuses are set to unknown when the subcloud goes offline (see https://github.com/starlingx/distcloud/blob/a4b30db3cc01c12da4c1dcb24ba7c8afc751c682/distributedcloud/dcmanager/manager/subcloud_manager.py#L1514). 
So I think we are covered here because the subcloud must be offline before it can be deleted, and nothing other than cert-mon will be changing endpoint statuses after the subcloud is unmanaged. I have tested these scenarios, so I will add details.
It can only be either a bug or a task of a story, not both

/PATCHSET_LEVEL.message: LGTM,
Are there reasons not directly delete the alarms that are raised against the subcloud being deleted?
Re-working the deletion handling to clear the dc-cert endpoint alarm directly instead of updating endpoint state.

Currently, we need to unmanage the subcloud before deleting it, so there should be no risk for the other endpoints. I would expect we have the bulk clear alarm API and re-organize this part to improve the efficiency.

Offline discussion with Bin: there's a very small window where the certmon 24-hour audit could possibly re-raise the alarm during this delete. I think that's enough to change the code here to clear the certmon dc-cert endpoint alarm after the subcloud is removed (in the same place as there the offline alarm is cleared), which will avoid the situation.

It would be nice to do similar to line 1141~1158. Or better yet, to create a "clear_all_subcloud_alarms" function to loop through a list of DC alarm IDs (currently there are 2: offline and resource_out_of_sync).
My concern is that this implementation is not as efficient (calling update endpoint status unnecessarily), and easy to go wrong, i.e, in a rare case, a simultaneous resource audit could re-raise the alarm before the endpoint is deleted.

We could just clear the alarm, but thinking it's probably safer to set the endpoint state to 'unknown', since both cert-mon and dcmanager generally only operate on the endpoint status. If more behaviour is ever bundled in to the endpoint state changes keeping it consistent would pay off here (rather than going straight to clearing the fault).

Agreed in part. In discussing this with Tee and Yuxing, our thinking is that what we really need is a fault API to provide the equivalent 'clear_all_subcloud_alarms' function. I'm raising an enhancement request for this, but the thinking is that until we have that this new API it is sufficient to follow the approach in the review. See Yuxing's TODO on line 1420 for example. So, in effect, we're putting this in place now and will re-visit/optimize this when a new fault API is available. Make sense to you?

For the last point, in the delete case the subcloud must be both unmanaged and offline to get through the delete code to this point, so there shouldn't be any concurrency concerns here. 
I'm not super concerned about efficiency for the subcloud delete case since it such a rare operation. And my reasoning is that given cert-mon is operating on the subcloud sync_status, for now it makes sense to keep operating on that level when going to delete the subcloud.

Changed to directly clearing both the offline and dc-cert out-of-sync alarms.
This is done at the end of the delete to eliminate any race condition with cert-mon.
Responding to Tee's question
lgtm

distributedcloud/dcmanager/manager/subcl.message: This looks more like a warning, not a TODO?

Yes, good catch, and this comment needs editing since we decided not to add the RPC calls to cert-mon for subcloud_unmanaged / subcloud_deleted. In fact, the cert-mon edge case here may prevent the original TODO entirely. i.e. we won't be able to do the batch clear because the cert-mon out-of-sync alarm will always be an outlier. 

The comment is updated to note this.
Why is there a need to attempt to clear this? Isn't it the current behavior?

Yes, it is the current behaviour, We were previously only clearing FM_ALARM_ID_DC_SUBCLOUD_OFFLINE.  Now now we are also clearing FM_ALARM_ID_DC_SUBCLOUD_RESOURCE_OUT_OF_SYNC.

I simply made the two clear_fault calls in a loop here rather than two separate calls - reasoning: the code and exception handling is the same for both.
